description: From Latin exōtericus, from Ancient Greek ἐξωτερικός (exōterikós, “external”), adjectival form of ἐξώτερος (exṓteros, “outside”).

adjectives.description: exoteric (comparative more exoteric, superlative most exoteric)

entries.meaning: Suitable to be imparted to the public without secrecy or other reserves
examples: The foppery of an exoteric, and an esoteric doctrine.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Accessible; capable of being readily or fully comprehended; or, having an obvious application
examples: The grouping together of folk and elite might be termed relatively "esoteric", in contrast to the more "exoteric" popular forms.

entries.meaning: (rare) Public or popular; having wide currency
